result.execSummary:
The defendant Theresa M Schaffner was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Possession of Methamphetamine, a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(3g)(g).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

parties.name: Polk County Clerk of Circuit Court

miscConds.notes: Must pay a $250.00 DNA surcharge to Probation while on Probation.
Must complete HSED or GED while on Probation.
May not possess or use firearms or body armor.
Must complete a Mental Health assessment & comply with recommendations.

May not vote or hold public office until civil rights are restored.  Other civil rights may be lost until restored.  
If not a US citizen, may face deportation or loss of other citizenship rights.
Must complete an AODA assessment & comply with recommendations.
$290.60 fine/cost to be paid to the Clerk of Court's Office within 60 days or set up payment plan.  Failure to pay may result in a warrant.

timeConds.notes: Banked/stayed for use by Probation if necessary.
25 hours of Community Service for each year of Probation for a total of 75 hours.

supervisions.notes:
Subject to Good Time & Work Release.
304 days sentence credit  = TIME SERVED.

Any outstanding financial obligation still due and owing will be reduced to a civil judgment and payable at the Clerk of Court's Office.
May not vote or hold public office until civil rights are restored.  Other civil rights may be lost until restored.  
If not a U.S. citizen, may face deportation or loss of other citizenship rights.
May not possess or use firearms and, if considered a violent felony, no body armor.
